item.title: Call Of Duty: Black Ops 7 -- See Wall-Running And Active Camo In Action, Plus Other Major Multiplayer Changes
item.content:encoded:
GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

Call of Duty: Black Ops 7 has been revealed in greater detail as part of Gamescom, and one of the key changes to the Omnimovement system is the addition of wall-jumping.

As you can see in the video below, wall-jumping allows the player to zip across the map in a way that may feel familiar to longtime fans of Call of Duty since some older games also had wall-running. Some are comparing this to some of the exosuit-powered abilities from Call of Duty: Advanced Warfare, and indeed, it does look like the wall-jumping will provide for new ways to get the drop on enemies.

FIRST LOOK: NEXT LEVEL OMNIMOVEMENT
Omnimovement is more dynamic than ever, with enhanced movement tuning and the addition of Wall Jumps for fluid traversal.
Additionally to further refine the movement in #BlackOps7, Tactical Sprint will shift into a selectable Perk. pic.twitter.com/LOhz0nowlt

— Call of Duty (@CallofDuty) August 19, 2025

The addition of wall-jumping is just one of many changes to the multiplayer formula in Black Ops 7 that Dexerto outlined. GameSpot also got to see and play the game already.

Black Ops 7 also does not have tactical sprint by default--now, players need to use a perk for it. Additionally, there is no more aim-down-sights while sliding, diving, or wall-jumping without the use of a perk. There is also a new Gung Ho perk that allows players to sprint while firing.

Players can also expect a new active camo field upgrade in Black Ops 7 that allows players to become temporarily invisible--here's how that looks:

Additionally, manual doors on multiplayer maps are gone. In Black Ops 6, players could open and close doors, or peek them, but in Black Ops 7, the doors are not manually operated. Another major change for Black Ops 7 is the introduction of a new social feature that allows players to quickly share their weapon builds with others.

In terms of new modes, Black Ops 7's multiplayer package adds a 20v20 mode called Skirmish that features wingsuits and grappling hooks. This is in addition to core 6v6 maps that the series is known for.

At launch in November, Black Ops 7 will have 16 6v6 maps--13 are new and three are remakes from Black Ops 2. Skirmish will have two maps at launch. There will be 30 weapons available at launch, including 28 ranged weapons and two melee. Of the 30 weapons, 16 are brand-new to Call of Duty.

A multiplayer beta for Black Ops 7 kicks off in early October, allowing players to try out some of Black Ops 7's new multiplayer features. The full game, meanwhile, launches on November 14.

Activision will show off more of Black Ops 7's multiplayer during Call of Duty Next in September, at which time the company will also reveal more of the Zombies mode.

Keep checking back with GameSpot for the latest on Call of Duty: Black Ops 7, but for now, you can read up on everything we learned from playing the game via the links below.

  • Call Of Duty: Black Ops 7 Release Date Set For November, CoD Next Coming In September
  • CoD: Black Ops Again? Black Ops 7 Does Plenty To Avoid Feeling Like DLC
  • CoD: Black Ops 7 Will Let You Level Up And Earn Rewards In Its New Campaign Endgame
  • Call Of Duty's Carry Forward Returns For Black Ops 7--But With Limitations

Got a news tip or want to contact us directly? Email news@gamespot.com

item.title: WoW: Midnight Opening Cinematic Once Again Puts The Sunwell Under Siege
item.content:encoded:
GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

Blizzard revealed the opening cinematic for World of Warcraft's next expansion, Midnight, as part of Gamescom Opening Night Live, setting the stakes for the second chapter in the game's multi-expansion Worldsoul Saga and proving it ain't easy being a Blood Elf.

The cinematic depicts Xal'atath, the current big bad of the Warcraft universe, commencing a full-scale invasion of the Blood Elf homeland Quel'Thalas. Blood Elf leaders Lor'themar and Liadrin face off against Xal'atath and her shadowy Void beasts, but it soon becomes apparent that they can do little to stop this threat.

Xal'atath's objective seems to be the Sunwell, a potent font of magic power that has been the target of hostile forces multiple times in Warcraft history. First, Arthas and his Scourge army corrupted the Sunwell to create the lich Kel'thuzad back in 2002's Warcraft 3: Reign of Chaos, an event that led to the former High Elves changing their name to Blood Elves to begin with.

Fast forward a few years and disgraced Blood Elf prince Kael'thas Sunstrider would attempt to restore the Sunwell to its former glory…albeit with the goal of using it to open a portal for a Burning Legion invasion. Players put a stop to that back in 2008 as part of WoW's The Burning Crusade expansion, but with some help from the Draenei, the Sunwell would ultimately be restored as a font of both arcane and holy power.

What Xal'atath wants with the Sunwell isn't exactly clear, but it certainly can't be good. Thankfully, the Light seems keen on stopping her and her Void army, and Liadrin and Alliance forces, seemingly empowered by the Light, push back the encroaching foes.

Maria Hamilton, associate design director on WoW, told GameSpot in an interview that while it's true players have seen the invasion of Quel'Thalas and the Sunwell before, the nature of this fight is quite different. The Light isn't taking a backseat this time around, and the heroes of Azeroth will have to contend with some never-before-seen Void creatures.

"The Light is quite actively involved in this fight," Hamilton said. "This is a fight between Light and Void and the Light is there, it is visible and present."

Xal'atath has become a fan-favorite villain in the WoW community, and this cinematic is the first time players have gotten to truly see just how powerful she is. The cinematic shows she's capable of inflicting mental anguish with just a blink of the eye, though Lor'themar is eventually able to overcome the psychic attack.

Cinematic director Ben Dai told GameSpot the cinematics team wanted to leave room for imagination when it came to Xal'atath's true power, choosing to hold back on showing her at her full potential. The less she does, the more powerful she feels, Dai said.

"That's just the tip of the iceberg of what she can do," Dai said. "We want to leave everything else to the game to let the player explore."

It's after that initial battle depicted in the cinematic that players will begin the Midnight expansion, which will revamp the Blood Elf lands of Quel'Thalas first introduced in 2007 to be more in line with the modern version of the game. The expansion will also introduce player housing in full, add a new Allied Race in the form of the Haranir, make major changes to transmog, and bring a third, Void-powered specialization for Demon Hunters. WoW's Midnight expansion does not have an exact release date just yet but is slated to arrive in early 2026.

Got a news tip or want to contact us directly? Email news@gamespot.com



https://www.gamespot.com/articles/wow-midnight-opening-cinematic-once-again-puts-the-sunwell-under-siege/1100-6534002/?ftag=CAD-01-10abi2f

item.title: Resident Evil Requiem Trailer Explores The Backstory Of New Heroine Grace Ashcroft
item.content:encoded:
GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

Today during Gamescom Opening Night Live, Capcom debuted a new trailer for Resident Evil Requiem, which gave a brief look at protagonist Grace Ashcroft's origin story--as well as a look at her mother, Alyssa Ashcroft, a journalist who appeared in Resident Evil Outbreak way back in 2003.

The trailer begins with Grace and Alyssa in a hotel room, where Grace receives a phone call; the man on the phone asks for her, then immediately hangs up. Suddenly, the lights of the entire hotel go out, and things spiral from there.

Eventually, the two women find the hotel manager, who begins to apologize for the power outage and says he'll fix it immediately. Suddenly, the man is attacked by a hooded figure--who also happens to have pale white skin resembling the undead or the zealots of Resident Evil 4--with a plastic bag, sending the Ashfords running for their lives. Grace walks ahead of her mother, and when she turns to say something, she screams ... and the trailer ends.

The trailer provided a little more information about Grace, who was the playable character in the hands-on preview Capcom showed off when it announced Resident Evil Requiem in June. The reveal trailer for Resident Evil Requiem found Grace as an FBI analyst years after her mother's death, so this look at the game fills in some of those gaps.

This was one of many trailers to debut during Gamescom Opening Night Live, which also featured updates for The Outer Worlds 2, Ghost of Yotei, and Silent Hill F. Among the newly-announced games at the event were Lords of the Fallen 2, Lego Batman: Legacy of the Dark Knight, and Black Myth: Zhong Kui, the follow-up to Black Myth: Wukong from Game Science.

Resident Evil Requiem is set to launch February 27, 2026 on Xbox Series X|S, PlayStation 5, and PC.

Got a news tip or want to contact us directly? Email news@gamespot.com

item.title: Kingdom Come Deliverance 2's Second DLC Gets Trailer And Release Date
item.content:encoded:
GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

Kingdom Come: Deliverance 2's next expansion, Legacy of the Forge, now has a release date--and it's soon. The second story DLC for the popular RPG will launch on September 9.

This was announced at Gamescom Opening Night Live in Cologne, Germany alongside a trailer showing it off. "Put your blacksmithing skills to the test as you rebuild a burnt-down forge in the heart of Kuttenberg. Design and customise the workshop, its surroundings, and your private quarters--with upgrades that do more than just look good," reads a line from the expansion's description. Here's the trailer:

Kingdom Come 2 launched in early 2025 and got free updates that added things like horse racing and a hardcore mode. The first paid expansion, Brushes with Death, launched in May. After Legacy of the Forge will come Mysteria Ecclesia later in 2025. People can buy the expansion's individually or in a $30 bundle.

The game sold 2 million copies in its first two weeks and went on to climb to 3 million in the first three months. Kingdom Come Deliverance 2 also earned rave reviews, including a 9/10 here at GameSpot.

Developer Warhorse has also supported the game with official mod support that has allowed players to add all manner of wacky and weird things to the game.

Got a news tip or want to contact us directly? Email news@gamespot.com



https://www.gamespot.com/articles/kingdom-come-deliverance-2s-second-dlc-gets-trailer-and-release-date/1100-6534101/?ftag=CAD-01-10abi2f
